{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3656992,"name":"Josh Targo","username":"joshtargo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/7bcc69/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-18T01:31:28.723Z","cooked":"

For certain reasons, we can’t use a cascade system for our 3 stage lift. but if we do a continuous chain, something on the innermost stage will crash into one of the sprocket shafts. Is there a way to have a continuous-style strung lift, but split it up so the drive sprockets and some stages are on one plane and some other stages are on another plane? Maybe using hex shaft and sprockets to transfer energy between the planes? No idea if this makes sense or if it’s possible.

image492×841 46.5 KB

I want to change the full-width upper rear shaft into just a sprocket next to the plate so the motor can pass by. I know there are other solutions that may not require that, but i want to know if its possible to split a continuous rigged system.

kinda sketch ngl
why chain continious over dyneema?
Also why not rig it on the vertical plane, instead of the horizontal plane like 6328?

Two Questions:

  1. What’s preventing the motor from just being shifted up on the final stage a few inches?
  2. Can you link your CAD? Easier to understand how the mechanism operates when I can pan around.

If you just want to terminate that upper shaft, maybe you could add a spanner plate with three bearing holes just to the left of the upper sprocket. The other two shafts would ride in the other two bearings and support the upper shaft.

I’d have to play with it more, but I’m worried that the inside loop won’t stay tight.
If you do go this way, you need to get all four chain runs parallel to the motion of the slides.
